qas.question: When was Government phonology first seen?
Jonathan Kaye is an important person in what form of phonology?
What is responsible for differences in surface realizations according to Government phonology?
When were government principles first seen?
Jonathan Kaye is an important person in what form of conflict?
What is responsible for differences in surface realizations according to government conflict?
What vary according to their selection of government?
What is true of all languages' field parameters?

context: <a1_0><b4_0>Government<b4_0/><a1_0/> phonology, which originated in <a0_0><b3_0>the early 1980s<b3_0/><a0_0/> as an attempt to unify theoretical notions of syntactic and phonological structures, is based on the notion that all <b6_0>languages<b6_0/> necessarily follow a small set of principles and vary according to their selection of certain binary parameters. That is, all languages' phonological structures are <b7_0>essentially the same<b7_0/>, but there is <a2_0><b5_0>restricted variation<b5_0/><a2_0/> that accounts for differences in surface realizations. Principles are held to be inviolable, though parameters may sometimes come into conflict. Prominent figures in this field include Jonathan Kaye, Jean Lowenstamm, Jean-Roger Vergnaud, Monik Charette, and John Harris.
